repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Renewable Energy for Rural
            Economic Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Renewable Energy
            for Rural Economic Development Project for Sri Lanka were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; GEO outcomes were also
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible; risk to GEO outcome was also low or negligible;
            Bank performance was satisfactory and the borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: long term involvement is very important. A quality
            implementation body is vital. Private sector market growth
            should be carefully managed where possible. Stakeholder
            consultation throughout the project cycle is necessary. Risk
            analysis should be carried out also during implementation.
            Performance-based incentives to selected developers are key
            in enabling communities to get expert support. Prepare well
            for project closure. World Bank involvement added credibility.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Renewable Energy for Rural
            Economic Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Renewable Energy for Rural Economic
            Development Project, aims at improving the quality of rural
            life, by utilizing off-grid renewable energy technologies,
            to provide electricity in remote areas, and, in addition,
            promote private sector power generation from renewable
            energy resources for the main grid. The key components of
            the project are: 1) grid-connected renewable energy power
            generation, by enabling, on a large scale, the refinancing
            support for mini-hydro projects, and, by extending support
            to two other commercially available renewable energy sources
            - wind and biomass; 2) solar photovoltaic (PV) investments,
            by integrating refinance, grants, and technical assistance
            (TA) support, aiming at solidifying the existing
            middle-range solar home system market, and expand to smaller
            systems accessible to the poor, and community applications
            for health clinics, schools, public services; 3) independent
            grid systems, which will support commercialization of
            village hydro, and other community-based independent grid
            systems, through refinancing, and grant support. TA will
            address issues such as electricity use for income generation
            activities, once the grid connection is in place, while the
            status of independent grids within the sector reform agenda,
            will be emphasized in the broader sector TA; 4) TA, and
            limited credit support to prod private sector development in
            the provision of energy efficiency services, and demand side
            management will be provided, including the integration of
            sustainable implementation of such programs into sector
            reforms; 5) cross-sectoral energy applications, i.e.,
            provision of credit support to rural enterprises, TA to
            service institutions for energy development, and
            co-financing support for investments in selected areas; and,
            6) TA (in addition to the component-specific assistance) for
            project administration, subproject promotion, technology and
            capacity building, and, monitoring and evaluation.
